Award.AwardTitle: Quality Data Is the First Step: The National Homicide Data Improvement Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this study is to improve dramatically the quality of data on homicides for the United States since 1959. By augmenting the data gathered in recent years by the National Violent Death Reporting System, and by using statistical tools to estimate the number of homicides that occurred in various social, demographic, and geographical groups, the Project will for the first time give scholars and law enforcement officers a highly accurate long-term homicide series. Preliminary analyses document the extent to which reliance on extant datasets has distorted knowledge of homicide in the United States. For some categories of homicide, the researchers have found that merging police and vital statistics homicide records at the state level can increase the tally of homicides by as much as 30 percent over the numbers available from police reports alone. By combining (a) data reported by police to the FBI, with (b) data reported by health officials to their state vital statistics agencies and to the National Center for Health Statistics and the National Child Abuse and Neglect Data System, augmented when necessary by (c) internal police records and newspaper accounts, the project will create homicide data series that are as complete as possible. The research will be conducted initially in Ohio and then in four more "open record" states (California, Connecticut, Massachusetts, and North Carolina), so named because their death records are available for examination and chosen because they represent four different regions of the country.

This research may improve the development and implementation of policies concerning child abuse, domestic violence, and homicides among unrelated adults, and will permit the testing of hypotheses concerning the impact of homicide rates on clearance rates and other forms of deterrence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The fundamental purpose of our “National Homicide Data Improvement Project” is to improve the quality of data on homicides in the United States, 1959-present. As has been clear in the recent debate over shootings of or by law enforcement officers, no one has been keeping an accurate record of such lethal assaults, which is one of the many gaps that our project fills. We discovered, for instance, in our pilot project on Ohio, that only sixty percent of all homicides in non-urban counties were reported to the FBI in late 1960s and 1970s, a result that left law enforcement blind to the extent and character of homicide in rural and suburban counties. We also found that more than a quarter from the entire state were missing from the statistics compiled by the National Center for Health Statistics. The problems have been addressed since 2003 in a growing number of states by the National Violent Death Reporting System, which has encouraged law enforcement agencies, health department officials, and medical examiners to work together to gather more complete and comprehensive data on homicides. But the system is not retroactive, so it cannot help scholars, public officials, or the public understand the dramatic changes in the character and incidence of homicide that have occurred since the late 1950s.

            The goal of the project is thus to give everyone—scholars, public officials, and the public—access to the high quality data necessary to explain why crime rates rise or fall, and to make better decisions on public policy. Substantively, however, we believe that the data are already yielding insights into the causes of rising or falling homicide rates. It will take several more years to enter the evidence we have gathered into our database and to create narratives of the more than 20,000 homicides we are studying. But we can already see, for instance, how broad based the rise in homicide in the late 1960s and early 1970s was, touching all kinds of communities, families, and relationships, in contrast to the surge among young men in the late 1980s and early 1990s, which was concentrated in particular neighbors and particular relationships. And we have been struck by the dramatic decline in homicides among persons ages 25 and older, which has occurred almost steadily since the mid-1970s for African Americans, Asian Americans, and Native Americans, and since the early 1980s for European Americans. Explaining these changes will be no easy task, but knowing that they happened and when the happened is the critical first step. That is why we’ve focused on the data. Sound explanation can only emerge from sound data.
